Periods of inactivity, isolation from athletic teams, distance from the athletic community, less qualified 63 interactions with athletic coaches, and lack of social support (e.g., fans, sports organizations, media, etc.) World-class athletes might not face financial problems, but the cancellation of leagues and 81 competitions that are a source of income will greatly affect many teams around the globe (Toresdahl &   82 Asif, 2020). While teams and coaches might try to find ways to save elite athletes first, lower-level 83 athletes are prone to more challenges under these conditions. Therefore, governments must consider prevention strategies for the future. Learning from the past economic crises caused by previous 86 pandemics, planning for the current situation, and eventual future prevention strategies would seem to 87 require the establishment of a specific task force.

In summary, in critical situations, health authorities and sport communities must identify their 89 priorities and make plans to maintain athletes' health and athletic activities. Several aspects play an 90 important role in prioritization and strategic planning, e.g., physical and mental health, distribution of 91 resources, and short to long-term environmental considerations.

Due to the multi-dimensional impact of pandemic-related consequences for elite athletes, as a 66 unique population, analytical studies to identify circulating bio markers, time-course of effect and 67 negative impact, and response to coping strategies or treatment interventions (e.g., Psychological First 68 Aid intervention) (Yang et al., 2020) might be useful, and in line with the bio-psycho-social approach. 69 Management strategies, therefore, need to include physical and mental treatment for infected 70 athletes and optimize athletic environments, which are influenced by geographical locations, 71 governments, and time-resources, for training and recreation. Some attempts to standardize and give 72 recommendations are on the way (Schinke et al., 2020). Artificial intelligence and digital-based platforms 73 can potentially provide immediate help, and consequently, recommendations or psychological 74 interventions can be provided.75In planning for the post-COVID-19 pandemic, sport related organizations must consider a regular 76 built-in infection control measure of risk-benefit evaluation and the available resources needed to 77 administer it in a team training environment. Essential travel after re-opening should be evaluated and 78 decided on a case-by-case basis, balancing benefits, risks, and risk mitigation options, which might be 79 affected by the damaged post-pandemic economy.
